abstract: Many airlines now forbid brachycephalic breeds, short-faced animals with breathing issues, on their planes, causing inconvenience for their owners and opening a niche for companies that cater specifically to pet travel; on recent Pet Airways flight from Republic Airport in Farmingdale, NY, 5 of 15 canine passengers were brachycephalic breeds.
snippet: Many airlines now forbid brachycephalic breeds, like bulldogs and pugs, from their planes, causing inconvenience for their owners — and opening a niche for companies that cater to pet travel.
lead_paragraph: Many airlines now forbid brachycephalic breeds, like bulldogs and pugs, from their planes, causing inconvenience for their owners — and opening a niche for companies that cater to pet travel.

headline.main: Banned by Many Airlines, These Bulldogs Fly Private
headline.print_headline: Banned by Many Airlines, These Bulldogs Fly Private
headline.seo: Banned by Many Airlines, These Bulldogs Fly Private
